Articles.Content:
Just got an idea for a new kind of experiment: Long Term Study

Set up a base, click lab pod (would have to be a new part most likely, recolored hitchhiker for starters?) to start study.

longtermStudy module notes the starting time index and sets a time in the future (days, weeks, months later) as a goal.

The GUI command "show progress" displays a percentage value, which is really a recalculated countdown showing the time left for the study to finish. (15% completed = 15/100 days into the study)

Science value of the study is determined by length and biome/body/orbit.

Further studies in the same location take longer and are less rewarding (science/day quota) to encourage new bases.

Advantage to "steady trickle":

Player can leave the base and do something else, as the module only looks at the time and tells him "nope, not yet ready".

Additions:

Maybe surface samples from x different locations have to be stored and are used up in the process.

Module could check if current power production and storage capacity are sufficient - easy method, start consumes a certain amount of energy and experiment fails if batteries are depleted.

A mimimum number of personnal has to be present in the base/craft.

Whatever is possible for the game to check and makes sense really.
I really like this idea. It gives bases, stations and other long-term craft scientific purpose.
My only suggestion is for it to use your system or ping your ISP for a time check, otherwise it would be heavily exploited. And shorten the time to minutes, hours, and days in real time.

Sharp - I think the plan is to use KSP-time; so while in theory you could simply Time-Warp your way through the countdown if you have no other missions going on, you can run other missions in the meantime.

Exploited by setting up several bases - a feat by itself - and letting the game run at 1000000000x speed over night?

If that is the way a player wants to do it - nobody calls it exploiting when we do it while waiting for a transfer window or for a ship to arrive.

I intentionally suggested long ingame time intervals to give a reason to built a longterm installation - of a reasonable size, therefore the requirements for energy and personnal - because there are always players questioning the value of space stations and bases. There is currently no direct ingame reason for them and I wanted to come up with something to encourage their construction.

Harvester has said no to time-based experiments. It just won't happen, regardless of whether it has merit or not. IMHO, the exploit of running experiments over time, whilst novel, has no real gameplay value due to timewarp, and is equivalent to having it run instantly.

Time has no meaning in KSP at the moment except for launch windows, so there's no reason to build time into the gameplay mechanic until Time becomes a more important factor.

Bummer ... because a similar mechanic could be used to built automatic mining plants to calculate production. (dt * capacity)

An internal clock already exists, it is used to calculate the position of planets, moons etc.

But you are right, there are no deadlines or anything time-critical in the game.

But(2) why does the antenna then take so much time to transmit data?

But(3) while you timewarp you do nothing else - and why timewarp to do science if there is the sandbox?
Well if things like supplies life support and money come into play, you need to make money to support long term missions. I think at that point long term experiments could be implemented.

Bummer ... because a similar mechanic could be used to built automatic mining plants to calculate production. (dt * capacity)

An internal clock already exists, it is used to calculate the position of planets, moons etc.

But you are right, there are no deadlines or anything time-critical in the game.

But(2) why does the antenna then take so much time to transmit data?

But(3) while you timewarp you do nothing else - and why timewarp to do science if there is the sandbox?

2) Not a clue; presumably because the distances involved mean that data packets seems like the most 'realistic' way of sending data

3) Because in career mode there will be other objectives later on, so they didn't want to build a game mechanic which they would then have to change.
